description.narrative: This contribution covered the country-level support for the implementation of the series of Council of Europe multi-annual Action Plans for Ukraine, from 2008-2011 through the period of 2015-2017. This intervention comprised six components/sub-projects implemented in the period from 01 January 2010 to 30 September 2016. The projects were of different nature and duration, with some thematic ear-marking for the key reform areas where Council of Europe has added value and unique expertise (justice system, local governance, elections, countering gender-based violence, penitentiary system). The intervention also included an organizational development component aiming to stengthen Council of Europe's development work at the country and regional level. The evaluation of multi-annual Action Plan as an instrument at the early stage of this contribution helped to enhance the tool, making it more efficient, functional, country-specific and need-based. This element of the overall programme had a noticeable transformative effect on the Council of Europe programmatic activity in general, both in the field and at the headquarters level. The Ukraine Action Plan modality was used as best practive for other country Action Plans, which sufficiently enhanced the KPIs of Council of Europe development work of the on the whole and enhanced national ownership of the country Action Plans. The six components/sub-projects of this contribution were as follows: Component 1: "Local Democracy in the Council of Europe Action Plan for Ukraine" (01 January 2010 - 31 March 2013; actually spent 8 387 995 SEK) Component 2: “Support and Evaluation of the Action Plan” (1 March 2011-30 September 2013, 5 000 000 SEK) Component 3: “Support for Prison Reform in Ukraine” (1 March 2011-30 September 2013, 8 000 000 SEK) Component 4:“Pre-electoral assistance support” (15 March 2012 - 15 November 2012, SEK 2 700 000) Component 5: "Improving the Ukrainian Justice System in Line with European Standards" (01 January 2013 - 31 December 2014, SEK 6 625 409) Component 6: “Preventing and Combating Violence against Women and Domestic Violence in Ukraine" (01 September 2013 - 30 September 2016, SEK 9 799 334) The total budget for the intervention, as initially planned, was SEK 57 000 000. The amount spent and reported is SEK 40 512 738. All the remaining funds under each subcomponent have been repaid to Sida. This expenditure level reveals an absorption rate problem for the Council of Europe for this intervention (30%). This was partially caused by the political developments in the country (Revolution of Dignity 2013-2014 followed by Presidential and Parliamentary election in 2014), which affected the implementation of all the policy and legal framework segment in this programme. Due to external factors many activities were postponed, delayed or cancelled, political will for a number of planned reforms changed substantially etc. In terms of reporting, the first five components under this contribution have previously been completed, closed and duly archived as separate sub-projects. The planned results were mostly achieved and created good basis for successor projects of the Council of Europe in the respective thematic areas. This Memo aims to summarize the results under the final Component VI "Preventing and combatting violence against women and domestic violence in Ukraine". The deliverables planned for this Project were partly achieved despite the country’s unstable political, economic and conflict-related situation. The main project aim was the ratification of the Istanbul Convention by the Ukrainian authorities, including the preparation for ratification and the implementation of the Convention in law, policy and practice. This is a questionable approach from the point of view of project design, as Council of Europe set the project aim beyond their direct control. In the end this aim was not achieved due to a number of external factors (resistance of the Council of churches and their influence on the Parliament being the main obstacle). The project focused on the traditional implementation modality for Council of Europe, i.e. transfer of expertise. The project team has provided the national partners (government, Parliament, civil society) with reports on legislation, data collection and local multi-agency co-operation as envisaged, containing recommendations to the state authorities that could serve as a practical guide for further developments towards meeting the Istanbul Convention requirements. National and regional stakeholders have been deeply involved in all project activities in order to ensure an active and fruitful implementation of the project and the stakeholders’ ownership of the process and its results. In this sense, the project has partially met its overall objective, i.e. enhanced the capacity of national institutions to prevent and combat violence against women and domestic violence, and raised awareness among the relevant law- and policy-makers responsible for ensuring the existence of effective assistance and redress to victims of violence against women.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
